questions.text: A 34-year-old male was on maize as a staple diet for a prolonged period. He presented with diarrhea and lesion over his neck as shown in the image below. The condition occurs due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Niacin

Explanation:

  • Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:
    • Dermatitis: Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet).Casal’s necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck
    • Diarrhoea
    • Dementia.

Causes of pellagra :

  • Dietary Deficiency- Maize and Sorghum based diet
  • Factors Affecting Tryptophan to Niacin Conversion:
    • Vitamin B6 Deficiency
    • Medications: Isoniazid (INH), OCPs
    • Hormonal Influences: Estrogen metabolites hinder tryptophan metabolism.
    • Genetic Disorders: Inherited conditions like Hartnup disease can impede tryptophan absorption in the intestines and reabsorption in the kidneys
  • Carcinoid Syndrome
  • Other Contributing Factors:
  • Alcoholism: Interferes with nutrient absorption, including niacin and tryptophan.
  • Malabsorption Syndromes

Incorrect Options:

Vitamin B12 deficiency (Option B) can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, neurological issues, and anaemia. However, it is not typically associated with the specific combination of dermatitis, diarrhoea, and cognitive disturbances seen in this case.

Rickets (Option C) resulting from a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, present with bone deformities and growth retardation. It is not associated with dermatitis, diarrhoea, and neurological symptoms characteristic of pellagra.

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option D) can cause fatigue, pallor, and shortness of breath but does not typically present with skin rash, gastrointestinal symptoms, or cognitive issues associated with pellagra.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent stages in the vitamin D metabolism necessitates exposure to sunlight?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 7-dehydrocholesterol to cholecalciferol

 

Explanation:

The conversion of 7-dehydrocholesterol to cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) is the stage in vitamin D metabolism that requires exposure to sunlight.

 

This reaction occurs in the skin under the influence of UVB radiation from sunlight.

  • 7-dehydrocholesterol is a compound found in the skin, and when exposed to UVB light, it is converted to cholecalciferol (vitamin D3).

 

Vitamin D Metabolism:

  • Skin (sunlight exposure): 7-dehydrocholesterol is converted to cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) under UVB light.

 

  • Liver: Cholecalciferol is then converted to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (calcidiol), the major circulating form of vitamin D.

 

  • Kidneys: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is further hydroxylated to form the active metabolite, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol).

questions.text: Which of the following substance, facilitate the absorption of dietary iron?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Vitamin C

Explanation:

Vitamin C enhances dietary iron absorption by:

  • Reducing Ferric to Ferrous Iron: Converts ferric iron (Fe³⁺) to the more absorbable ferrous form (Fe²⁺) in the acidic stomach environment.
  • Chelation: Forms a soluble complex with iron, preventing it from binding to inhibitors like phytates and tannins.
  • Enhanced Transport: Improves iron uptake by intestinal mucosal cells.

questions.text: A young boy presented with fissured tongue, lips, and lesions in the angle of the mouth.On investigation, he had low RBC glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin is deficient here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Riboflavin

Explanation:

Riboflavin or Vitamin B2 acts as the coenzyme flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) in oxidation and reduction reactions.

Lesions of the corner of mouth, lips, and prosthetic group of flavoproteins.

  • The main dietary sources of riboflavin are milk and dairy products. In addition, because of its intense yellow color, riboflavin is widely used as a food additive.

Riboflavin deficiency leads to following signs and symptoms:

  • Cheilosis: It is pallor in the angle of mouth and fissuring of lips.
  • Glossitis: Loss of papilla and increased smoothness of tongue
  • Eyes: Keratitis, conjunctivitis, subcorneal congestion(ist sign) •
  • Seborrheic dermatitis
  • Anemia

For Vitamin B2 deficiency - RBC or erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity should be checked.

questions.text: What is the underlying cause of the presenting symptoms in a 21-year-old individual with chronic alcoholism who is admitted to the emergency department with confusion, tremors, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vitamin B1

Explanation:

Thiamine deficiency is the first seen micronutrient deficiency in chronic alcoholism, as alcohol interferes with thiamine absorption.

  • The patient's symptoms of confusion, difficulty walking (cerebellar ataxia), and abnormal eye movements (nystagmus) are classic signs of Wernicke encephalopathy, which is caused by thiamine deficiency often seen in chronic alcoholics.

WERNICKE-KORSAKOFF SYNDROME (CEREBRAL BERI-BERI)

Clinical Manifestations

Wernicke Encephalopathy:

Symptoms: Ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia, global confusion.

Korsakoff Psychosis:

Symptoms: Anterograde and retrograde amnesia, sensory agnosia, and confabulation.

Causes of Thiamine Deficiency in Alcoholics
  • Increased thiamine requirements due to alcohol consumption. Alcohol is a source of empty calories.
  • Inhibition of intestinal thiamine absorption by alcohol.

Metabolic Implications
  • Impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • Accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood.
  • Potential for life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Progression and Risk Factors
  • Progression from Wernicke encephalopathy to Korsakoff psychosis if untreated.
  • Associated with severely compromised nutritional status, often due to chronic alcoholism.

MRI findings

Symmetrical T2/FLAIR signal increase in the mammillary bodies, dorsomedial thalami, tectal plate, periaqueductal area, and around the third ventricle.

questions.text: A baby presents with the clinical features shown in the image, including characteristic perioral and perianal rash along with a history of diarrhea. Which of the following is the most likely deficiency responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Zinc Deficiency

 

Explanation:

  • Characteristic rash: The image likely shows acrodermatitis enteropathica, which presents with perioral, perianal, and acral dermatitis—a hallmark of zinc deficiency.
  • History of diarrhea: Zinc plays a crucial role in intestinal function and immunity; its deficiency leads to chronic diarrhea.
  • Other symptoms of zinc deficiency: Growth retardation, poor wound healing, alopecia, and immune dysfunction.

Zinc Deficiency & Acrodermatitis Enteropathica

Feature

Zinc Deficiency

Cause

Congenital (SLC39A4 mutation) or acquired (malnutrition, chronic diarrhea)

Key Skin Features

Perioral, perianal, and acral dermatitis with erythematous, scaly plaques

Other Symptoms

Growth retardation, diarrhea, alopecia, immune dysfunction

Diagnosis

Low serum zinc levels

Treatment

Zinc supplementation

Niacin Deficiency (Option B) is incorrect because niacin deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by the "3 Ds"—dermatitis, diarrhoea, and dementia—but the rash is photosensitive and occurs in sun-exposed areas, not perioral/perianal.

 

Selenium Deficiency (Option C) is incorrect because selenium deficiency primarily affects the cardiovascular system (e.g., Keshan disease, causing cardiomyopathy) and does not cause a perioral/perianal rash.

 

Magnesium Deficiency (Option D) is incorrect because magnesium deficiency presents with neuromuscular symptoms (tetany, muscle cramps, seizures) rather than a characteristic rash.

questions.text: To evaluate a deficiency of vitamin B2 (riboflavin), one can assess the activity of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Glutathione reductase

Explanation:

Laboratory Tests for Vitamin Deficiencies:

Vitamin B1 (Thiamin):

  • Test: Measure transketolase activity in red blood cells with and without thiamin diphosphate.
  • Indicator: Increased activity with thiamin diphosphate indicates deficiency.

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin):

  • Test: Measure glutathione reductase activity in red blood cells with and without flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD).
  • Indicator: Increased activity with FAD indicates deficiency.

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine):

Test:

  • Measure activation of red blood cell transaminases with pyridoxal phosphate.
  • Xanthurenic acid in urine Indicator: Increased activity indicates deficiency.
  • The metabolic disorders that respond to vitamin B6 therapy include xanthurenic aciduria and homocystinuria.

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin):

Tests:

  • Urinary methylmalonic acid: Elevated levels indicate impaired conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA, suggesting deficiency.
  • Megaloblastic anaemia assessment: Detects anaemia caused by disrupted folate metabolism due to B12 deficiency.

Folate:

Test:

  • Assess for megaloblastic anaemia.

Indicator:

  • The presence of this type of anaemia suggests folate deficiency.
  • When folic acid is deficient, FIGLU is excreted in urine.
  • Histidine can be transaminated with pyruvate to form imidazole pyruvate and alanine.

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of delayed adaptation to vision in dark places, gritty sensation in the eyes, dry eyes, and softening of the cornea. What is the likely deficiency in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retinoic acid

Explanation:

Vitamin A Deficiency Manifestations :

1. Ocular manifestations :

  • Vitamin A deficiency is the most significant preventable cause of blindness, especially in children below 5 in developing countries.
  • Early Signs:
    1. Loss of sensitivity to green light.
    2. Difficulty adapting to dark places .
    3. Night blindness.
  • Prolonged Deficiency:
    • Xerophthalmia:
      1. Dry, thick, keratinized conjunctiva and cornea. If untreated, it leads to corneal ulceration and ultimately results in blindness due to the formation of opaque scar tissue.
      2. WHO grading of xerophthalmia:

XN
  • Night blindness.

X1
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis.
  • X1B: Bitot spots.

X2
  • Corneal xerosis.

X3
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration, less than one-third.
  • X3B: Corneal ulceration, more than one-third.

XS
  • Corneal scar.

XF
  • Xerophthalmic fundus.
  •  
    • Bitot's Spots: Grayish-white triangular plaques firmly adherent to the conjunctiva.
    • Keratomalacia: When xerophthalmia persists for a longer time, it progresses to keratomalacia (corneal softening).

2. Immune Function:

  • Deficiency increases susceptibility to infections.
  • Infection reduces retinol-binding protein synthesis, lowering vitamin A levels and impairing immune responses.

3. Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions:

  • Follicular Hyperkeratosis (Phrynoderma): Causes rough skin due to hyperkeratinization of the follicular epithelium.
  • Keratinizing Metaplasia: Affects respiratory, gastrointestinal, and genitourinary tracts.
  • Epithelium is atrophied.

4. Other General Manifestation :

  • Growth retardation due to defective synthesis of chondroitin sulfate.
  • Decreased protein synthesis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B) Riboflavin: Riboflavin deficiency typically manifests as oral and ocular symptoms, such as cracked lips, inflamed tongue, and sensitivity to light (photophobia).

Option C) Niacin: Niacin deficiency, also known as pellagra, primarily presents with dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

Option D) Pantothenic acid: Pantothenic acid, or vitamin B5, deficiency is rare and not commonly associated with eye-related symptoms. It is involved in energy production and plays a role in various physiological processes.

questions.text: A farmer presented with loose stools and rashes over the sun-exposed areas. Careful diet history reveals a diet rich in maize. Which of the following deficiencies would you suspect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Niacin

Explanation:

  • The Clinical scenario of Diarrhoea, rashes over sun exposed areas (Dermatitis) and a history of maize based diet indicates Pellagra, seen in niacin deficiency
  • Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:
    • Dermatitis
      • Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
      • Casal’s necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck (image)

 

  • Diarrhoea
  • Dementia

The patient's symptoms, combined with a diet high in maize and sorghum, both known to contribute to niacin and tryptophan deficiencies suggest pellagra as the most likely diagnosis.

Sorghum has high leucine content which inhibits the QPRTase enzyme required for synthesis of Niacin from tryptophan. Additionally, Maize is low in tryptophan.


Incorrect Options:

Option B) Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) deficiency can lead to various neurological symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, but it is not associated with specific skin rashes or gastrointestinal symptoms like loose stools.

Option C) Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency typically presents with symptoms related to the nervous system, such as peripheral neuropathy, cardiovascular abnormalities, and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Option D) Biotin deficiency is rare and usually occurs in individuals with a genetic disorder or those consuming large quantities of raw egg whites, which contain a protein called avidin that binds to biotin and impairs its absorption. Biotin deficiency can lead to symptoms such as hair loss, skin rash, and neurological abnormalities.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with itchy lesions as shown in the image. He also has a red-colored beefy tongue. Which of the following histories would you like to ask/elicit in this patient additionally?

choices.text: Ask for diarrhea and a history of memory loss
Ask for diarrhea, thiamine deficiency features, and detailed dietary history

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ask for diarrhea and a history of memory loss

Explanation:

  • The Clinical scenario of Alcoholic, Red beefy tongue and Casal’s necklace (Dermatitis) in image indicates niacin deficiency
  • Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:
    • Dermatitis
      • Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
      • Casal’s necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck (image)

​​​​​​​

  • Diarrhoea
  • Dementia

The patient's symptoms, combined with a diet high in maize and sorghum, both known to contribute to niacin and tryptophan deficiencies suggest pellagra as the most likely diagnosis.

Sorghum has high leucine content which inhibits the QPRTase enzyme required for synthesis of Niacin from tryptophan. Additionally, Maize is low in tryptophan.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B) Ask for diarrhea, thiamine deficiency features, and detailed dietary history: While thiamine deficiency is a potential concern in alcoholics,it features (muscle weakness, fatigue, cardiovascular symptoms).

Option C) History of allergy: Allergies can cause skin manifestations, including itching, the specific symptoms mentioned in this case are indicative of a condition associated with alcohol abuse and thiamine deficiency.

Option D) Ask for diarrhea and conjunctivitis: Conjunctivitis (pink eye) and diarrhea are symptoms that can be associated with certain infections.

questions.text:
Which of the following are vitamin B12-dependent enzymes?


	Methyl malonyl CoA isomerase
	Homocysteine synthase
	Folate reductase
	Methionine synthase
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1 and 4 only

Explanation:

Vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methyl malonyl CoA isomerase
  • Methionine synthase

Methylmalonyl CoA isomerase: This enzyme is dependent on vitamin B12. It catalyses the isomerisation of methyl malonyl CoA to succinyl CoA, which is an important step in the metabolism of certain fatty acids and amino acids.

Methionine synthase: This enzyme is dependent on vitamin B12. It uses methylcobalamin as a cofactor to catalyse the conversion of homocysteine to methionine, a critical step in the synthesis of methionine and the recycling of homocysteine.

synthase enzyme " data-author="" data-hash="12346" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" height="452" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/C6J00NelhR7oldZqpISu1746609391.png" width="511" />

 

 

Homocysteine synthase: This enzyme is not directly dependent on vitamin B12. It utilizes methylcobalamin, a form of vitamin B12, as a cofactor to catalyze the conversion of homocysteine to methionine. However, it is not strictly considered a vitamin B12-dependent enzyme.

Folate reductase: This enzyme is not directly dependent on vitamin B12. It is involved in the metabolism of folate (vitamin B9) and plays a role in the synthesis of DNA and other important cellular processes.

questions.text: The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Skin-liver-kidney:

The synthesis of vitamin D involves three key steps:

  • Skin: UVB radiation converts 7-dehydrocholesterol into cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) in the skin.
  • Liver: Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol) by the enzyme 25-hydroxylase.
  • Kidney: Calcidiol is further hydroxylated to the active form, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol), by 1α-hydroxylase.

  • This sequence ensures the production of bioactive vitamin D necessary for calcium and phosphate homeostasis.
  • Calcitriol plays a crucial role in calcium and phosphorus metabolism and responsible for regulating their blood levels.

questions.text: Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Competitive inhibition:

  • Dicoumarol is a structural analog of vitamin K.
  • It acts as a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which is essential for recycling vitamin K to its active form.

Competitive Inhibition

  • Inhibitor binds to the active site of an enzyme, competing directly with the substrate.
  • The inhibitor’s presence prevents the substrate from binding, thereby reducing the enzyme’s activity.
  • However, increasing the substrate concentration can overcome this inhibition.

Key Features:

  • Binds at the active site.
  • Reversible: Substrate can displace the inhibitor if present in excess.
  • Km increases: Higher substrate concentration is needed to reach half-maximal velocity ().
  • V max remains unchanged: At high substrate concentrations, the enzyme can still achieve its maximum velocity.

Examples:

  • Dicoumarol: Inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase, blocking vitamin K recycling.
  • Sulfonamides: Compete with para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) for the active site of dihydropteroate synthase, inhibiting bacterial folate synthesis.
  • Statins: Compete with HMG-CoA for HMG-CoA reductase, reducing cholesterol synthesis.
  • Methotrexate: Competes with dihydrofolate for the active site of dihydrofolate reductase, inhibiting nucleotide synthesis.
  • Ethanol: Competes with methanol or ethylene glycol for alcohol dehydrogenase, used in cases of poisoning.

questions.text: Which vitamin, when infused in supraphysiological doses, causes macular edema and macular cysts?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vitamin B3

Explanation:

  • Niacin toxicity (Vit B3) can lead to macular edema and cysts through increased prostaglandin synthesis, resulting in fluid accumulation in the retina.

Mechanism of Macular Edema and cysts:

  • Niacin can raise levels of prostaglandins, particularly prostaglandin D2 (PGD2).
  • Elevated prostaglandin levels lead to increased vascular permeability in the retina.
  • Increased vascular permeability causes fluid and proteins to leak into the retinal layers, resulting in macular edema.
  • Patients may experience blurred vision and distortion in their visual field.

Management:

  • Reducing or stopping niacin can resolve the symptoms.
  • Patients on high doses should be regularly monitored for ocular side effects.

Other effects of niacin toxicity includes:

  • Flushing: Caused by the release of prostaglandins leading to vasodilation.
  • Gastrointestinal Distress: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal discomfort.
    • Due to increased gastric acid secretion and irritation of the gastrointestinal lining.
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hyperurecemia

questions.text: Which antioxidant deficiency can cause the symptoms of iron-deficiency anemia, painful and tender joints, and bleeding manifestations in a 34-year-old woman who primarily consumes packaged and reheated meals?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vitamin C

Explanation:

Vitamin C deficiency develops after weeks to months of vitamin C depletion.

Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency, also known as scurvy, can cause:

  • Iron-deficiency anemia: Impaired non-heme iron absorption.
  • Painful, tender joints: Due to defective collagen synthesis affecting cartilage.
  • Bleeding manifestations: Easy bruising, gum bleeding, and perifollicular hemorrhages due to weakened capillary walls from defective collagen.
  • Scorbutic rosary
  • Risk factor: Diet lacking fresh fruits and vegetables, relying on packaged and reheated meals, as heat destroys vitamin C.

Glutathione (Option A): Involved in oxidative stress protection, no direct link to these symptoms.

ß-carotene (Option B): Precursor of vitamin A, deficiency affects vision and skin, not bleeding or anemia.

Zinc (Option D): Deficiency causes delayed wound healing and dermatitis, not anemia or bleeding.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of the worsening neurological symptoms in a 30-year-old woman who presented with complaints of fatigue, difficulty breathing during exertion, weight loss, and frequent falls, and was found to have bilateral decrease in vibration sense, a hemoglobin level of 8.2 g% with high MCV, and was initially treated with folate which improved her anemia?

choices.text: Folic acid therapy unmasked pyridoxine deficiency.
Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS.
Folate therapy caused rapid use of vitamin B12 stores aggravating symptoms.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Folate therapy caused rapid use of vitamin B12 stores aggravating symptoms

Explanation:

  • These are classic symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency, which leads to impaired DNA synthesis (macrocytic anemia) and demyelination (peripheral neuropathy).

Folate supplementation in isolation:

  • Folate can improve the hematologic symptoms (macrocytic anemia) by bypassing the impaired DNA synthesis caused by B12 deficiency.
  • However, folate does not address the neurologic symptoms caused by the lack of B12, which are due to accumulation of methylmalonic acid and demyelination in the central and peripheral nervous systems.

Mechanism of worsening symptoms:

  • When folate is supplemented without correcting B12 deficiency, it increases the demand for B12 in the methylation cycle (conversion of homocysteine to methionine).
  • This depletes the already low B12 stores, worsening the neurologic symptoms, despite initial improvement in anemia.

questions.text: Which of the following contains the maximum amount of vitamin B12?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Animal products

Explanation:

  • Vitamin B12 is primarily found in animal products such as meat, fish, eggs, and dairy.
  • Plant-based sources like green leafy vegetables, roots, tubers, and vegetarian diets generally lack significant amounts of vitamin B12 unless fortified or supplemented.
  • So Vit B12 deficiency is significantly seen among plant sources.

Symptoms:

  • Hematologic: Macrocytic anemia, fatigue, pallor.
  • Neurological: Paresthesias, ataxia, memory loss, peripheral neuropathy.
  • Psychiatric: Depression, irritability, cognitive decline.
  • Glossitis: Sore, red, swollen tongue.

Diagnosis:

  • Low serum vitamin B12 levels.
  • Elevated methylmalonic acid (MMA) and homocysteine levels.
  • Peripheral blood smear: Macrocytes, hypersegmented neutrophils.

questions.text: What is the probable reason for the worsening of neurologic symptoms in a patient who initially showed improvement in blood picture after receiving a dose of 5mg folate for peripheral neuropathy and macrocytic anemia?

choices.text: Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency
Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS
Folate therapy using the B12 stores

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Folate therapy using the B12 stores.

Explanation:

  • These are classic symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency, which leads to impaired DNA synthesis (macrocytic anemia) and demyelination (peripheral neuropathy).

Folate supplementation in isolation:

  • Folate can improve the hematologic symptoms (macrocytic anemia) by bypassing the impaired DNA synthesis caused by B12 deficiency.
  • However, folate does not address the neurologic symptoms caused by the lack of B12, which are due to accumulation of methylmalonic acid and demyelination in the central and peripheral nervous systems.

Mechanism of worsening symptoms:

  • When folate is supplemented without correcting B12 deficiency, it increases the demand for B12 in the methylation cycle (conversion of homocysteine to methionine).
  • This depletes the already low B12 stores, worsening the neurologic symptoms, despite initial improvement in anemia.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 45-year-old male patient with a history of chronic alcoholism, who is currently experiencing symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and diplopia?

choices.text: Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

Explanation:

  • This patient is presenting with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy, commonly seen in patients with chronic alcoholism. The treatment for Wernicke's encephalopathy is to administer thiamine (vitamin B1) before or simultaneously with glucose to prevent exacerbating the condition.

WERNICKE-KORSAKOFF SYNDROME (CEREBRAL BERI-BERI)

Clinical Manifestations

Wernicke Encephalopathy:

Symptoms: Ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia, global confusion.

Korsakoff Psychosis:

Symptoms: Anterograde and retrograde amnesia, sensory agnosia, and confabulation. (Option B)

Causes of Thiamine Deficiency in Alcoholics
  • Increased thiamine requirements due to alcohol consumption. Alcohol is a source of empty calories.
  • Inhibition of intestinal thiamine absorption by alcohol.

Metabolic Implications
  • Impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • Accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood.
  • Potential for life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Progression and Risk Factors
  • Progression from Wernicke encephalopathy to Korsakoff psychosis if untreated.
  • Associated with severely compromised nutritional status, often due to chronic alcoholism.

MRI findings

Symmetrical T2/FLAIR signal increase in the mammillary bodies, dorsomedial thalami, tectal plate, periaqueductal area, and around the third ventricle.

Treatment

Acute Phase (Wernicke Encephalopathy):

  • Intravenous thiamine (100 mg) for 3-7 days is standard; however, higher doses (500 mg TID) may be required if symptoms persist.
  • Glucose should be administered after thiamine to prevent exacerbating symptoms.

Chronic Phase (Korsakoff’s Psychosis):

  • Continue oral thiamine indefinitely, especially in alcohol-dependent patients.
  • Address co-occurring deficiencies, provide nutritional support, and consider rehabilitation or residential care if needed.

Glucose infusion followed by thiamine injection (Option B): Giving glucose before thiamine can exacerbate Wernicke’s encephalopathy, as it can increase the metabolic demand for thiamine, worsening the deficiency.

Glucose infusion alone (Option C): Glucose infusion without thiamine can precipitate or worsen Wernicke's encephalopathy in patients with thiamine deficiency (such as in chronic alcoholics).

Thiamine infusion alone (Option D): While thiamine is essential, glucose infusion is also necessary if the patient is hypoglycemic. Thiamine alone is insufficient for immediate management if glucose is needed for the patient’s energy requirements.

questions.text: A patient has come in with bleeding gums and the examination results are as follows. This particular condition can be observed in the case of a deficiency in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vitamin C

Explanation:

Vitamin C is essential for collagen production. Its deficiency causes scurvy, leading to symptoms like bleeding gums, swollen gums, and delayed wound healing.

Vitamin C

  • Dietary Sources: Amla, guava, lime, lemon, and green leafy vegetables.
  • Requirements: The daily recommended intake is 75 mg/day, increased to 100 mg/day during pregnancy, lactation, for the elderly, smokers, and those on oral contraceptives.
  • Scurvy:
    • Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, which can be severe in infants between 6–12 months (infantile scurvy or Barlow’s disease).
    • Hemorrhagic Tendency: Collagen is abnormal in vitamin C deficiency, causing fragile capillaries that lead to bleeding under pressure, seen as petechiae or ecchymoses.
    • Internal Hemorrhage: Severe deficiency may cause hemorrhages in the conjunctiva, retina, nose (epistaxis), urine (hematuria), and stools (melena).
    • Oral Cavity: Severe scurvy causes swollen, painful gums, and tooth loss due to separation of pulp from dentine. Wound healing is delayed.
  • Bones: Vitamin C deficiency weakens bones, leading to fractures, joint hemorrhage, and pain due to failure of osteoblasts to form osteoid.
  • Anemia: Vitamin C deficiency causes microcytic, hypochromic anemia, with poikilocytosis and anisocytosis. Causes include blood loss, decreased iron absorption, and decreased tetrahydrofolic acid.

Vitamin A (Option A): Deficiency in vitamin A is associated with night blindness, dry skin, and impaired immune function, not bleeding gums.

Vitamin B12 (Option B): Deficiency in vitamin B12 leads to megaloblastic anemia, neurological issues, and glossitis, but not specifically bleeding gums.

Vitamin D (Option D): Deficiency in vitamin D can lead to bone issues like rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, but it does not directly cause bleeding gums.

questions.text: What is the probable vitamin deficiency in a patient who displays symptoms of diarrhea, memory impairment, and a distinctive rash as described?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Niacin

Explanation:

Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:

  • Dermatitis
    • Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
    • Casal’s necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck
